item.title: Advice for writing better note titles
item.description: Given a page within a PKM system, how do we write a good and useful title for it? Qualities we want:

item.title: All failure is systems failure
item.description: It is common to blame or praise a person’s character for their current state. It is more useful for all involved to point out and redesign the systems that enabled that state.

item.title: Andy Matuschak
item.description: The creator of one of my favourite digital gardens of all time: Andy’s working notes. Created with Bear and a custom workflow of his creation, visible in this 2020-05-04 Note-writing livestream

item.title: Backlink
item.description: A link that allows you to go visit sources that link to the file you are currently looking at. Called a Linked Mention by [[Obsidian]], similar to how social media notifies an account when it is Mentioned.

item.title: Backups that work
item.description: You likely know what a backup is: a copy of something, stored away from the original. When the original is lost, the copy can fill its place.

item.title: Bear
item.description: A MacOS-only app for personal knowledge management. I used it for a short time, and like its aesthetic, but I prefer Obsidian and Logseq.

item.title: Berserk
item.description: ![[notes/images/berserk-banner.jpg]] Manga series and world by Kentaro Miura. I first encountered the series in the early 2000s as a young teen, in its anime adaptation.

item.title: Computer
item.description: The first computer I ever used would have been on my family’s 486DX-33 beige computer running a mighty 33Mhz on a single thread and 8 megabytes of RAM, connected to a beige 14" CRT monitor capable of 320×240 pixel resolution.

item.title: Data down, actions up
item.description: A rule or convention for making more maintainable component based web applications. The rule being, allow components to pass data such as text input to their children, and allow children to pass actions such as clicks to their parents.

item.title: Digital garden
item.description: A digital garden is a website, with content on multiple pages which link to each other. Differentiators from blogs A digital garden is very similar to a blog.

item.title: Elden Ring
item.description: Possibly my favourite videogame of 2022. Also the first [[Souls-like]] game I ever played. Fun things in the game By far my favourite part of this game is being able to talk about it with friends and colleagues of whom many are playing it.

item.title: EmberJS
item.description: A framework for making Single page apps. Popularised a UI engineering technique called data down, actions up. EmberJS was made in a highly opinionated way that favours convention over configuration, and learning these conventions is the most difficult part for UI engineers new to Ember.

item.title: Every productivity system stops working eventually
item.description: One of the most important things to know about productivity routines and systems is that none are invincible. GTD, Pomodoro, [[Animedoro]], Kanban, Agile, Pair Programming — all will eventually fail.

item.title: Github pages
item.description: A service provided by [[Github]] for hosting HTML pages. These notes are currently hosted with them, but these testimonials make me nervous:

item.title: Hero’s Journey
item.description: ![[notes/images/Heros_Journey_diagram.jpg]] An extremely common trope, featuring a Hero character who is called to adventure, is victorious, and returns home changed.

item.title: Hieronymus Bosch
item.description: Netherlandish artist who painted Christian horror until his death in 1516 AD. There is an “official” website, and a project with high resolution scans, the Bosch project.

item.title: Hugo
item.description: A [[Static site generator]] built in [[Golang]]. Has a reputation for being incredibly fast, and feature rich. It also has a reputation for having terrible documentation.

item.title: Jurassic World: Dominion
item.description: The movie feels mostly like a chaotic carnival ride. You can expect some laughs and involuntary screams. That can be fun!

item.title: Maggie Appleton
item.description: https://maggieappleton.com/

item.title: My favourite blogs and digital gardens
item.description: My personal notes are heavily inspired by the personal notes, blogs, and digital gardens of many others. The ones I love the most Andy’s working notes by [[Andy Matuschak]] is extremely enjoyable to read.

item.title: My organisation system
item.description: I believe fervently that a good PKM system needs the following: A default place for new notes. When you want to write something down, you should not need to think about where to write, you should just write.

item.title: Personal Knowledge Management
item.description: Personal Knowledge Management (PKM) is the skill of managing one’s life knowledge, secrets, and experiences so that they can be reused, relived, and built upon to create other work.

item.title: Quartz
item.description: A tool for publishing Obsidian to the web, and what I’m using for this note you’re reading now! It’s built on top of Hugo, which I’m told is very fast, but can be hard to use.

item.title: Single page app
item.description: When you click a link or button, you might see the screen turn white as new page is loaded. Single page apps avoid loading any new pages at all, hence the name.

item.title: Software engineering
item.description: The creation, delivery, and maintenance of software that can withstand great loads. This requires the application of many other skills, which may include:

item.title: Trope
item.description: A storytelling tool, that has happened often enough to earn a name. Some tropes pander to a particular demographic. TV Tropes has more.

item.title: Typography
item.description: The arrangement of typed words for aesthetics and readability. Made up of some smaller skills including Font selection, Type arrangement, Punctuation.

item.title: UI engineering
item.description: A branch of [[software engineering]], specialising in the creation of user interfaces to view and interact with data. A UI engineer may take a mostly complete [[UI design]] and convert it into a single page app, which connects to data from a back end.

item.title: Videogame
item.description: The first videogame I ever played was likely a Pac-Man rip-off when I was around 4 years old, on the family computer.
